div1.p: [Hench] seeks further help from Mrs. Phillips in acquiring detailed information on the location of Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to Mrs. R. Hart Phillips, August 28, 1940

August 28, 1940
Mrs. R. Hart Phillips
Manzana de Gomez, 553
Havana, Cuba
My dear Mrs. Phillips:
div1.p:
I remember with appreciation the services you were able to render
me on my recent trip to Cuba on the historical researches in connection with yellow
fever. May I call upon your further services? I need considerable help, and hope indeed
that you, already knowing considerable of what I am trying to do, can help me further.
I am trying to obtain documentary evidence from several individuals in Havana. I am
enclosing carbon copies of my letters to them which will explain my desires. I am sure
it would be useless for me to hope to get any real information if these individuals
were to write me long hand, and if possible, I am anxious that you shall act for me
not only merely in the capacity of a secretary, but in the capacity of a strenuous
questioner and a hard-boiled taskmaster: If, for some reason, you cannot interview
these persons yourself, I would appreciate it if you would obtain the services of a
reliable secretary and supervise the job in a general way with the help of Mr. Moran.
May I suggest that you wait a few days after receiving this letter in the hope that
some of these persons will spontaneously telephone you for an appointment to answer
these questions. But if they do not do so rather promptly, I would appreciate it
greatly if you would telephone them very diplomatically and offer your services as my
agent. I hope that they will come to your office, but if this does not seem feasible,
please make a memorandum of whatever taxicab expenses you have, and I shall be only too
glad to reimburse you, and pay your regular secretarial charges.

Naturally, the two most important statements are those Senora
Rojas and from Dr. Agramonte's daughter, Senora Rodriguez Leon. May I hope that, being
a woman, you will exert a woman's wiles and make these good ladies talk in as detailed
a fashion as possible. I suspect that it might be much easier for you and for your
interviewers if Mr. Moran could at least go with you to visit Senora Rojas and Senora
Rodriguez Leon. He may be able to ask, at the appropriate time, some pertinent questions
or correct some statements, or make some leading inquiries which will help greatly. I
am sending him a carbon of this letter.

Of course, the most important thing of all is to have Senora Rojas
draw on a map which I am sending her, as accurately as possible her recollection of the
situation and general size of Camp Lazear. Will you or Mr. Moran particularly get her
to do this and authenticate her identification perhaps by citing on the photograph in her
own handwriting something as follows: “This is where the experimental camp (Camp Lazear)
used by the U.S. Army physicians in 1900, was located on our San Jose farm.” Signed---etc.
(or words to that effect).

I have sent Mr. Moran quite a memorandum which I will ask him to let
you read after he has read it. I do not have enough copies to send you one also. This
will help you greatly in the interviews and I am sure that you will consider it confidential
and realize that if I have been too frank or been in any way unfair to any individual or
to the Cuban government in general, that this will be straightened out before any publica-
tions are forthcoming. I cannot tell you how much I appreciate your great help in this matter.
